I am very pleased to see, as has been the practice in recent times, this chamber being made available for the discussion of reports of this nature. As we all know, when there was only one chamber, the motion to take note of a paper was really almost farcical inasmuch as we may as well have added 'and be consigned to the garbage bin', because in fact papers never were aired. Of course, the papers represent substantial work. This one was done mainly by the department but many are done by committees which put in extremely large amounts of work on hearings and reports. They are designed as an essential part of our democratic process whereby people in the community are given the opportunity to express a view through parliamentary committees of various natures. Those reports are of considerable value and the more exposure they get in this place the better, whatever the subject matter. I would just like to put on the record my approval of this process that is now available and I hope that my support for that is evidenced by my presence here today. I also have an ongoing interest in industrial relations and remind the House that my maiden speech was on that very subject. I made those arguments from long experience-close to 25 years-of employing people in a large range of industries, including the transport sector. It is interesting to note that enterprise bargaining is as old as the process of employment. When we did not have unions and awards, enterprise bargaining was the only arrangement available. I have lived in a business environment of award structures, and I found that those people whom I wanted to employ usually wanted an enterprise bargain. I never found that the truck driver on line haul wanted to be paid the award. If they walked into your place looking for the vacancy that you had advertised and you said, 'I pay the award', they would say, 'Thanks very much' and tum round and walk out again. They did not want the award. They did not want the restrictions that it placed upon them; they wanted an enterprise bargain.

speaker: Mr Tuckey
theText: Anybody who goes back to that speech will find substantial pleas for anMC 1388 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 Strangely enough-and I know it is anathema to many union bureaucrats-the simple fact was that in the transport sector on line haul the truck drivers mostly wanted trip money. They wanted trip money because it allowed them some flexibility in getting from A to B-some might argue more quickly than they were allowed. It allowed them to meet their commitments and to earn good money if they could fit in an extra trip. In most freight situations you find that there is a load in one direction but not necessarily in the other: it is known as back loading. The drivers were very happy if they got an incentive for back loading and-surprise, surprise-they usually found a back load. If they were under the award, the truck came back empty. The union in that industry is held up to the community as being both powerful and influential, but out there on the ground the fellow who drives a truck in those sorts of situations was always anxious to strike an enterprise bargain. That was even more notable in our more remote areas. The people who chose to go there were of a more enterprising nature. Naturally they were not looking for an enterprise bargain that reduced their opportunity to earn money; they wanted an enterprise bargain that allowed them to earn more money. More importantly, they were able to get it. As I said in relation to back loading, in every case the deal recognised that the guy who owned the truck needed to make a profit to stay in business and create jobs. These fellows all understood that; they were the salt of the earth. I never could work out why people so loved driving a truck. In later years I was able to say to two or three of them, 'Would you like to own this truck?' They said, 'How could I do that, I haven't got any money?' I said, 'I'm quite happy to advance you in business, I'll guarantee your loan.' I did so on a number of occasions-being one of those villainous bosses who extract everything from the worker. I put four or five fellows, who had given me good service for three or four years, into a truck and let them subcontract to the business with which I was associated. As it was a cooperative, I was a director and not an owner. To the best of my knowledge, a number of them are still doing extremely well. One fellow was a Maori, and he and his wife were two of the hardest working people I have ever met. She could drive the truck better than he could-and did. These were the sorts of people whom I saw through five or six years of their business until they could stand on their own two feet. Not one of them let me down. They were the people who were willing to go into enterprise agreements, and willing to grasp the first opportunity to be an owner of a truck-even though this generally reduced their disposable income. They had to meet the payments on the truck, fuel tax and sales tax, and everything else associated with running one of those businesses. Prior to the last election we worked out that those costs were about $2,000 a week. There has never been a time when enterprise agreements were not in fashion; they just were not formalised. We now have a report on enterprise agreements in their formalised sense and I wish to make a few remarks about that. I want to repeat something I say from time to time. I have referred to it a little alreadythat is, this business of villainous, grasping bosses, which is the only sort of rhetoric which our trade union bureaucracy uses to defend their existence, to defend their salary structures and to defend their right to a living. They say, 'We have to protect you from those villainous employers. ' Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1389 As we know, we have 800,000 or 900,000 small businesses in Australia. It is argued that, if they took on one extra employee each, they would wipe out the unemployment pool. We know that is easier said than done. I would say 95 per cent of that group could never be categorised as villainous or grasping. They are frequently, and on most occasions, one of the workers. You can go into many of these workplaces around Australia and have some difficulty identifying the boss, because he looks awfully like everybody else in the workshop. If he is in shorts and long white socks, he is not the boss; he is the visiting salesman. These people are employers of a huge percentage of the Australian work force. They are on equal terms with them and frequently, as I just mentioned with the owner-driver truckie, have less disposable income than many of the people they employ. They also have a huge appreciation of the value of good employees, the ones who tum up to work regularly, are innovative and are committed to the work ethic. For the only reason that they do not want to lose them, they tend to pay them over the award. In other words, they have an enterprise agreement and it reflects those people's good performance. Every time we hear about this unfair dismissal law, it presupposes the bosses get to work every morning, particularly this group of small employers, and say, 'Who can I sack today? Ha, ha, ha.' Scrooge! businesses which had to retrench staff in large numbers. I talked to one bloke who cried about that situation, not just because he was asking people who had worked with him for many years to leave, but because he saw them as his major asset which he was obliged to dissipate. He saw it as having to sell the land on which his factory stood. He was more concerned how, if he survived the recession we had to have, he would recover this wonderful asset. He knew as he let them go that they were not going to go on the dole. They were the people who would find another job because they were good at their job and he was paying them over the award. He had an enterprise agreement with them going back decades and he shed a tear for those people and for himself because he knew what he was losing. These are the points I make when I hear this mythology that every employer is there to rob you, exploit you, and you therefore need a trade union involvement and an enterprise agreement. That is a lot of rubbish. The truckies never said, 'I want to apply for a job with you, Mr Tuckey. I want trip money. I want an enterprise agreement and, by the way, can I call up Billy Smith to come and hold my hand while I deal with you?' They were all about six feet tall. Their feet were nearly as wide as their shoulders. They did not need any help. If they had been dissatisfied with the way I was running the business, they would have given me a bit of advice on that too. There are thousands of these workers around the place. They have always got a job. They change them from time to time and they do not need anybody's help. They know their value, they know the market and they know what they want. They do not need any of this help. Consequently, they get to the point where, in terms of enterprise agreements, they find it all a bit of a joke. It is worse than that because on 20 March 1995 Deakin University put out the results of some interesting surveys done by a masters student, Glennis Hanley, under the supervision of Associate Professor Alan Hope in the School of Economics. I do not think Deakin would be considered a right-wing university. They pointed out some very interesting things which I would have thought was a great message to the trade union movement.

theText: During the recession we had to have I talked with people in certain smallMC 1390 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 The research found that, while the union members tended to be satisfied with traditional union issues, an important factor affecting a unionist's satisfaction related to relationship or communication issues, such as never seeing the trade union representative anymore. These issues included listening to members' concerns, keeping members informed about union affairs and giving members a say in how the union is run. 'The importance placed by unionists on relationship issues suggests that, with the larger union structures following amalgamation, rank and file members feel distant, even remote, from union hierarchy,' commented Ms Hanley. Another important finding of the research was that 40 per cent of members claimed that they joined the union because of either a perception of compulsion or actual compulsion. Of the remainder, only a small group, around 13 per cent, could be described as union 'idealogues' committed to the values of trade unionism. The research also revealed that, given trade union membership has fallen from 51 per cent of the employed work force in 1976 to around 35 per cent today, a significant proportion of union members, 40 per cent in this study, may be described as reluctant conscripts. A more realistic estimate of committed union members may be, in effect, about 25 per cent of the employed work force. Everything involved with this report, and the government's legislation, in terms of the value of that operation, is guaranteeing that group-the union bureaucracy-a place in doing deals for a very cynical work force. And, as we can see, most of them thought they joined the union to buy a job. I think that is one of the more disgraceful aspects of Australia today-the fact that people are still obliged to buy a job. In fact, coming back to those truckies, I have seen them come back to the industry four and five years later and be obliged to get a union ticket in order to pick up a load. They are then told that they owe five years of union dues, because when they were last in the union they did not write a letter withdrawing from the union. I think that too is outrageous. They had to buy a job at a price of $1,500 to $2,000. I think that that is an issue that might be the subject of a parliamentary inquiry. Ms HENZELL (Capricornia) (10.18 a.m.)-As usual, you could drive a truck through the comments made by the member for O'Connor( Mr Tuckey). The only example he could use of people who might be affected by workplace reform was that of the six-foot muscle bound truckie. The report we are talking about-Enterprise bargaining in Australia-summarises the issue up to December 1994 and it has some important findings for the new industrial relations measures that are being brought in by this government. I would like to refer to the report that we are debating today. I think some of the gains made are important. Overall, the findings of the report suggest that the period covered by the first report was characterised by a significant growth in enterprise and workplace agreements, particularly in the federal industrial relations system and in the service sector, with bargaining spreading across a large number of industries to cover a majority of employees in the federal system. Workplaces with new federal agreements were distinguished from other forms of agreement, because they were likely to deal with more issues, more likely to reward employees for putting in extra effort and hours, less likely to exclude groups of employees from their agreement, more likely to result in consistent wage increases for all employees, more likely to be seen by women and part-timers as giving them a fair chance to have a say in bargaining and more likely to be seen by women and part-timers as making them better off. This was in comparison, of course, with formal agreements in state industrial relations systems; the new federal agreements have advantages. To quote from the summary report, the federal agreements: Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITfEE MC 1391 Â· had greater coverage, and more effective representation of male and female employees Â· were perceived as showing generally better outcomes in terms of productivity, product quality and reliability, performance against external standards, operating costs and profitability Â· were less likely to record a deterioration in management/union cooperation as perceived by employees Â· were more likely to provide pay increases for employees, especially female and part-time employees Â· were less likely to be perceived by employees as having made them worse off. However, the report also notes some general dissatisfaction with workplace change. This was referred to in comments made by Mark Davis, in an article in the Financial Review, in response to the report. In spite of some of the very positive gains that the report mentions, to quote Mark Davis's report: The outcome of workplace change is often viewed negatively by employees, particularly in places where management fails to consult with its workforce. That is, obviously, a key issue of enterprise bargaining. There has to be effective consultation between management and workers. He goes on, in hIS review of the report, to say this: While collective agreements are estimated to cover 69 per cent of employees under the federal system, they cover only 21 per cent of the entire workforce because of the lower penetration of bargaining in workplaces regulated by State industrial systems. The report found that the most common workplace changes introduced last year were new technology, changes in work organisation, new training opportunities and employee performance appraisal. The report says negative perceptions amongst employees reflect an "intensification" of work and higher levels of pressure on workers, with most employees saying they were putting more effort into their jobs than in the past. I think that that is a key issue. Certainly, we recognise that the really quite radical changes made to the workplace-through enterprise bargaining and, in many workplaces, through structural changes-have resulted in a rise in concern, not only about future job satisfaction, but also about security of employment. That has also come out of the recession. To quote, again, from the summary report: A particular area of concern arose from evidence of employee dissatisfaction on several issues across all types of workplaces, whether or not they had agreements Â· there was a significant decline in satisfaction with management, perceptions of weakening job security, widespread increases in stress and growing dissatisfaction with employees' ability to balance work and family life Â· employees were almost as likely to think that workplace changes had made them worse off, as better offso it is about fifty-fifty on thatÂ· attitudes to workplace bargaining were more positive than attitudes to workplace change more generally, with employees in workplaces with new federal agreements substantially more likely to report they were better off than worse off because of workplace bargaining. Sometimes I suspect the opposition is wrongly seen as simply reflecting the view of employers. In fact, it is made up of a group of people who want good employment relationships and good employment conditions for employees in Australia. At the great risk of boring you, since I suspect you heard this remark from me in the House of Representatives chamber earlier this week, I would point out to the Main Committee that what the government and the opposition have in common when it comes to enterprise bargaining and employer-employee relationships is one very significant factor: not that the government represents employees and the opposition represents employers-which is nonsense-but that we all happen to be parents of children who are seeking employment in Australia. I no more want my children caught up in an exploitative time frame and exploitative work conditions than anyone in the government wants theirs in that position. I have vested an interest in continuing good employee-employer relationships in Australia. The member for Capricornia has suggested, as government members sometimes do, that the government has some sort of monopoly on enterprise bargaining and employer-employee relationships. I pick up the comments by the member for O'Connor( Mr Tuckey). I suspect that the whole concept of enterprise bargaining was in existence long before the present agreements were in place. The whole concept of enterprise bargaining is, frankly, something that suits the Australian workplace and the Australian work ethic. In my own experience in rural industries, shearers have always been a part of some form of enterprise hargaining. They choose to work on a contract rather than at an hourly rate because of the opportunities for remuneration that that offers them. I know that is particularly true in the transport area, as alluded to by the member for O'Connor. Transport drivers deliberately choose to enter into a trip rate rather than an hourly rate arrangement. They deliberately choose transport operators who will pay them above the award. And they deliberately choose to enter into some form of loose enterprise bargaining so they can negotiate such things as back loading in order to maximise their return. The operator is pleased to entertain them because he wants that truck loaded and because, frankly, enterprising employees are the very people he wants to employ. I am not one who suggests that out there in the workplace there are not some trucking operators who would be exploitative, given half a chance. Of course, there are. Sadly, that is part of human nature. But they are in the minority. Furthermore, I have witnessed-I could not say first-hand because I have never been a truck operator but I had produce on the truck that was affected-the retaliation of employees who have felt that a particular truck operator was in some way being exploitative. I well recall getting a phone message to the effect that the tomatoes that I had produced and that I thought were on a truck destined for the Melbourne market were bound for Hobart, across the ocean, and were about to be left in Hobart. The truck driver had chosen in his own retaliatory way, having got to Melbourne and feeling that he was being exploited by the truck operator, to put that truck on the Empress a/Tasmania and leave it there. That did not please me and it did not please the transport operator, and I guess it is a very poor illustration of enterprise bargaining, but I applauded the determination shown by that particular employee to hold an exploitative employer to ransom. Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITfEE MC 1395 There is not, on this side of the House-as is popularly imagined-some sort of desperate anti-union feeling. In fact, particularly in rural industries, enterprise bargaining has been a fact of life for years. As someone who came out of a labour intensive rural industry, I can indicate to the Main Committee that as a business we always paid above the award because we wanted to, because we wanted to keep in place our valued employees who were making a real contribution to the business. That was an unstructured form of enterprise bargaining. The concept of enterprise bargaining, far from being something on which the government has a monopoly, is something with which the opposition is entirely comfortable. It is wrong to create the impression of a them and us mentality about enterprise bargaining. The opposition is not anti-union and, frankly, we are anxious to enter into the sort of cooperation with employees keen to work that enables the total enterprise in Australia to be enhanced. Current enterprise bargaining agreements in Australia tend to take two forms: either certified agreements between the unions and the employers, or enterprise flexibility arrangements which are entered into between the employers and the employees. The significance of the secondary one is not that unions are excluded but that there is an opportunity for employers and employees to enter into independent negotiations if they so choose. The opposition does not seek to exclude employees from any of these arrangements. In fact, as I interjected to assist the member for Capricornia, the opposition seeks to ensure that existing minimum wage arrangements are retained, that occupational health and safety arrangements are retained. theText: We are here today to talk about the report entitledWednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1397 rhetoric in respect to the positions of our opponents and also we possibly laud our own positions; however, there are a few issues I would like to take up. Historically, in terms of Jobsback, the coalition also has a position on things like the basic reduction and erosion of award conditions, with, for example, the $3 an hour award wage proposed by the present Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard). Conservative coalition governments in various state jurisdictions are also doing some fairly extreme things. Their intention may not be for those actions to have extreme results but, coming from Victoria, and not wishing to labour the point about the Premier, the fact is that when you look at what is occurring in Victoria with respect to ordinary workers, and the conditions they face when they go to work every day, there has been a real impact. People come into my office every day of the week, as they do to the offices of members opposite. I do not know whether only people associated with the Labor Party come to my office and only people associated with the coalition go to their offices, but we seem to be hearing very different stories. Quite often, people come to my office who are in a situation where they have been subjected to a form of abuse with respect to their working position because of changes in the state award system which have severely impacted upon them and their families--wen with respect to their take-home pay. Certainly, when I speak about the question of the coalition's policies with respect to these issues and their result, I bear no ill will to the members opposite in personal terms. WhatI worry about is the actual result of those policies. No matter how well founded they may be in terms of theory and no matter how well founded they may be in terms of the members' personal views and their ideology, the fact is that, as we see happening in states like Victoria and Western Australia, those policies are just not working. I would take up another comment by the member for Wakefield with respect to his example about the truck being left on the boat. I can also quote some examples of personal experiences when I was working on a station in New South Wales, longer ago than I care to remember. The circumstances were that I was driving a tractor and I was getting three bucks an hour. I found out subsequently, about six months later, that every other worker on every other farm in the surrounding districts was getting five bucks an hour. The only way I was able to address that issue was to pull on my own personal little strike at the time we were about to plant the wheat, and that was quite effective. I guess it could be called enterprise bargaining; I guess that at the time. I saw it as being militant industrial action on an individual basis. In those circumstances it did work, and in those circumstances it was necessary. MC 1398 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 The person I was employed by was not a bad fellow, but the view he had related to his circumstances and the position that he held with respect to the business. The circumstance with many employers is not that they are bad-and I do not think that they are-but that they have a very clear and abiding commitment to their business and to what they are doing. That tends to give them a perspective which relates to their position and that is understandable-it is totally understandable. However, the question is: does that in the end mean a result which can be worse for workers than it should be? The answer there, I think, is yes. Also when we look at the question of what is seen as a fair and reasonable claim, whether it be through enterprise bargaining or through other forms of action or negotiation, the fact is that it is always better to look back, and see what was fair or unfair historically-to see how unfair it really was-rather than looking forward. Historical claims are always easier to understand and to accept. I have had numerous occasions where, in years gone by, as a union official dealing with employers, I have had the argument put to me, 'But we can't afford this.' That is often the case: no argument, that is often the case. But on quite a few occasions, in circumstances where we have reached an agreement on the basis of what the employer said was something that was not sustainable, I have gone back to that workplace 12 months later or whatever, and the fact is that it has been affordable and it has been achievable. The employer often is prepared to agree that was in fact the case, but then give you the same answer about any future claim you may make. Again, that is understandable from their position. With respect to the circumstances of the individual truck driver and the boat, I guess that enterprise bargaining in the more formal sense, as this agreement discusses, is about avoiding those sorts of circumstances. It is about having a situation where, if an employer and an employee do n.egotiate on a formal basis, we know what the ground rules are, we know where we stand. The circumstances are then that we do not have forms of industrial action of that nature taking place, or, if they are taking place, certainly they are on a much reduced level. That is one of the successes of the government's industrial relations reforms over the yearsand they have evolved in various ways-that there has been a major decrease, a historical low in industrial action. I know that there are other issues relating to that. There is also the question of the overall impact of the recessionary period; there is also the impact of job losses in particular industries. That has all, I suppose, created additional fear in people's minds about maintaining their jobs, and about their willingness perhaps to take action. It has also meant that areas of the work force that are traditionally not heavily unionised have grown while others have decreased. We are seeing a situation, over the last three years or so as the recovery has occurred, and as employment has improved in many of those industries, where industrial action is still at a historical low. I do not think you can say it is one or the other totally, but I think that there has to be some recognition given to the fact that the government's accord process, the negotiations and the reforms within industrial relations have had an impact. Both the member for Wakefield and the member for O'Connor( Mr Tuckey) commented that enterprise bargaining has always occurred. Agreed. No doubt about that. I guess I would say that much of what we do in this place-and I think it is the intention of both sides in terms of their beliefs-is regulate, to an extent, the operation of the economy. There are arguments about how far that regulation goes, and there are also circumstances where different variations on the theme occur. But the fact of the matter is that we are partly about trying to regulate Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 1399 the operation of society, and the circumstances of enterprise bargaining are such that there has to be a situation where there are more formalised approaches taken in general. The real issue is not the question of the six-foot truck drivers, or the very articulate smaller people who are, in fact, able to use their skills to good effect with reasonable or sometimes unreasonable employers. A work force is a very varied and different area, and people often require those sorts of regulations and rules in there to assist with the processes of agreements with employers. As a former union official and, I suppose, someone who has followed the classic sort of hack development that is often pointed out by the coalition with respect to Labor Party politiciansnot that is has done me that much good-I have often dealt with employees whose real problem has been a lack of knowledge with respect to their rights and a lack of understanding about how they work. I am sure that has been the experience of those opposite also. In those circumstances there is a need to articulate those views. In a situation such as the one in Victoria, where basically the guts of the rule book have been thrown out, the end result is that employees feel even more exposed, more unsure of what they are entitled to and more able to be taken advantage of, often by people who, I stress, are not seeking to take advantage of them. The employees are merely in the competitive environment of industrial relations, which has existed for an awful long time. They are endeavouring to maximise their own benefits from an involvement in the productive process while employers are about trying to maximise the benefit to them and their business with respect to profits and therefore income. That is understandable, but it does require regulations for the process. The Enterprise bargaining in Australia report is the first comprehensive review of developments in bargaining at the enterprise and workplace level. It covers a nine-month period from 30 March to 31 December 1994. The report was prepared by the Department of Industrial Relations and draws on several sources of information, including the department's formalised federal workplace agreements database, which contains information on federal enterprise agreements formalised by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which commenced operation in the period under review. The workplace bargaining survey 1994, which is the largest work based survey of both managers and employees undertaken in Australia to date, conducted nationally at 1,060 Australian workplaces with 10 or more employees, was another source of information. Research was conducted within and outside the department, including an analysis of transcripts and decisions from Australian Industrial Relations Commission hearings. Consultations were conducted for the report with a broad range of organisations with an interest in enterprise bargaining, including employer organisations, the ACTU and unions, groups representing women and ethnic communities, other community organisations and relevant government agencies. ThereÂ· was also consultation with the sex discrimination commission and the Affirmative Action Agency. The report reviews developments under part vm of the federal IR Act which has two types of enterprise agreements: certified agreements negotiated between employers and unions and enterprise flexibility agreements made directly between an employer and his or her employees, provided a majority of employees approve. The report concentrates on developments in the federal sphere but does provide some comparative data on workplaces in the formal state systems and workplaces with unregistered agreements. MC 1400 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 A number of messages come out of the report. I will be brief, given that I have probably spent too much time discussing the comments of previous speakers. The first message is that overall the extra protections for employees introduced through our legislation are having a positive effect. Bargaining under our federal system is fairer for employees. The comparative data within the report shows that, compared with other forms of agreement, new federal agreements are more likely to result in wage increases for all employees, and that women and part-timers have seen it as giving them a fairer chance to have a say within the process. More employees in workplaces with new federal agreements, some 63 per cent, had received a wage increase in the previous 12 months than had employees in other types of workplaces. The second message from the report is that the federal system not only is fairer but also is delivering better coverage. We have seen a significant increase in agreement making in the federal IR system and, through that process, by protecting employees, the government's reforms are helping to boost employeeÂ¥ participation in and confidence in bargaining. That will have a result with respect to the quality of work and industry undertaken through business, and that will have a better result for the economy as a whole. The system is delivering good economic results, with 96 per cent of agreements including at least one provision to improve productivity at the workplace and provisions relating to hours of work, training and work organisation found in the majority of agreements. Compared with unregistered agreements, new formal federal agreements were more likely to have received wage increases based on productivity, and nearly 80 per cent of workplaces with new federal agreements reported an increase in productivity in the previous 12 months. It is starting to show results, and I think results which go past the anecdotal discussions of, say, the member for O'Connor earlier today. The report also shows that a number of people who were critical of these reforms at the time have in fact been proved to be wrong. In the lead up to the Industrial Relations Reform Act, some employer groups and conservative commentators said that giving employers the right to strike when negotiating a certified agreement through a sanction-free bargaining period, taking the secondary boycott provisions out of the Trade Practices Act and dealing with secondary boycotts through the Industrial Relations Act would lead to a massive increase in industrial disputation. That just has not happened. Another argument, which was put by the ACCI and others, was that the federal agreements were just meaningless, that they would be add-ons to awards and in that way, clearly, are wrong. But, again, a review of the agreements that have been reached show that, arguably, only a small number appear to be simply add-ons. The circumstances were that agreements from the perspective of workplace managers were seen to have represented a complete settlement of the package of pay and conditions that ought to apply in a workplace or enterprise. Many of those agreements involved an overall restructuring of someone's award conditions but often the agreement addressed particular issues that were a particular problem with respect to that business. I had the experience, as an official in years gone by, where often the argument from an employer would be, 'It's this issue I want to fix. The rest I can live with. It's okay.' That is what has been addressed through this process. Overall, the report is a handy document with respect to the changes that have occurred. It shows that the reforms are moving in the right direction. I commend it to the House. (Time expired) Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 1401 a few remarks about the 1994 annual report on enterprise bargaining in Australia. It is interesting listening to members opposite speaking on the topic of industrial relations. The accusation of course comes out, as it inevitably did then, that some members on our side are inherently anti-worker. We would of course strongly dispute that. What we are in fact is proAustralia. It is quite clear that the industrial regime is absolutely critical to the future of Australia. The reason why we in Australia have dragged the chain so much in terms of the restructuring of our economy is simply that the government of the last 12 years has been hamstrung to a very large extent by its relations with the unions. We do not need to look any further than that as one of the major reasons why the restructuring of the Australian economy has been so slow-although there has been an increasing realisation on the other side of politics that it needs to be done. To their credit, I think some of the leadership of the Labor Party do know what needs to be done. I notice that the president of the Labor Party, the member for Lalor( Mr Barry Jones), is here this morning. Certainly, the Prime Minister( Mr Keating), I think, understands what needs to be done, as do some of his ministers. However, it has been made quite clear time and time again that they have been unable to deliver because they can go only as far as the union movement-the union leadership in particular-allows them to go. There is a fundamental conflict of interest within the Australian Labor Party and because of that they will never be able to deliver the structural reform of the Australian economy that the times demand. Mr Barry Jones-Do you think there was a faster rate of change under the Fraser government? on so far since 1983. I accept the criticism of many aspects of the Fraser government, but the fact is that in the last 10 years, when there needed to be an accelerated rate of change, the Labor Party has not been anywhere up to delivering that rate of change, in a world where there has been a realisation that there has been a rapid rate of change. Let us look at our Asian neighbours. In Singapore, for instance, the standard of living has doubled-however that is measured---every 10 years since the 1960s. The New Zealand economy---our government wanted to be critical of the process of change which was going on there at one stage-is now bearing the fruit from the in-depth accelerated structural change that has occurred, while we have been largely sitting on our hands. The Labor Party knew the directions that had to be taken. However, it has not been able to deliver and this report indicates that quite clearly. The report talks about the quantity of change. That was my impression in reading through it. On that measure, on the quantity of change, it looks very good. It is able to report, as the minister has reported in the parliament, about the extent of the coverage of the work force by enterprise agreements. theText: We could talk about the Fraser government. The caravan has movedMC 1402 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 of financial support given by the government to the unions is remarkable. In the last 12 years, between $130 million and $140 million of taxpayers' money has effectively been given to the unions by virtue of direct grants and tax concessions. All legallyMr Barry Jones-But there are no direct grants to the unions. yesterday. Government patronage of the union movement exists to that extent. The other side of the picture is more alarming because it is actually a two-way street. Prior to the 1993 election, the ACTU received grants of $1.3 million from the government for a whole range of purposes. It does not really matter whether or not it is called training-a lot of it is fairly specious. At least, on the face of it, it is not illegal. At the same time, the ACTU put $1.2 million into its campaign against the coalition at the 1993 election. Almost all the money it received in grants from the government was used against the coalition. The extent of the patronage that exists between the Labor Party and the trade union movement is such that, at that level, it is really a matter of the one who pays the piper calling the tune. That is why this country has been largely hamstrung in the area of industrial relations over the last 12 years. We are accused of being anti-worker but the government has operated in the interests of a small sector of the Australian community, the trade union leadership and some of their apparatchiks, to the great detriment of the majority of Australia and Australians, and that is the great pity of it. The government has been unable to deliver, other than in some quantitative sense, what was necessary. I would like to back up a bit here and say that, quite remarkably, in about 1991, the government came to a realisation that it had missed the boat in terms of industrial relation reform. Let us remember that, up to that point, it was totally intransigent on enterprise bargaining. It was something that we had talked about on our side of politics for many years, although, as the member for Lalor observed, the timing was not right and nothing was done prior to 1983. That is when the whole process of change in our part of the world, in particular, accelerated, although it had been happening in parts of Asia prior to that. The facts are that the government was finally dragged screaming to the realisation that there had to be a move into this new era of industrial relations. Prior to that, we were totally locked into the colonial system and the whole shebang, the whole box and dice, of arbitration and centralised wage fixing. The union movement realised too late that there had to be a change and the government was actually allowed-that is what it boiled down to-to go down that track. As I say, I believe some of them knew that that was the way to go, and I pay credit to those who were smart enough to know it. I suspect that many others were smart enough to know it too, but their factions tell them. I do not know which faction the honourable member for Corinella ( Mr Griffin) is in, but no doubt he is also told-how far to go down those tracks. The leadership of the trade union movement slowly woke up to the fact that they had to get with it and that they had no choice. So we have entered into this process of what amounts ultimately to a Claytons form of enterprise bargaining, because it has so many restrictions placed upon it-both legislative and otherwise-that it really is still failing today to deliver the pace of reform that the circumstances actually call for.

There is now a much greater appreciation-by management in particular, but also by workers by and large-that ultimately everybody is better off and the cake actually becomes bigger through an appreciation of what our profits and sales are actually all about. The recent report which showed that Australia was, in some senses, the wealthiest nation on earth should probably give us some comfort, but what it actually does is demonstrate, more clearly than anything else we have seen in recent times, the great gap that there is in this country between its potential and its actual performance. By almost every measure, our performance in economic terms is very poor. Ultimately, of course, our international competitiveness is the major problem that we are faced with in this country, in terms of making our way in the world with the ongoing balance of payments problems that we continue to have. The aims and objectives of the industrial relations legislation have been expressed as being to enable the spread of enterprise bargaining and the protection of employees' interests through the maintenance and strengthening of the award safety net. We come to an impasse in these sorts of debates when we talk about the status quo. The starting point for all of the negotiations, from the government's point of view and from the unions' point of view, has always been the status quo. It has always been assumed that, in some ways, that was the point to start at; whereas, quite clearly, in many respects it was not the point to start at. In fact, the safety net, as somebody observed the other day, rather than being a safety net had become a hammock for many employees. There is a need, of course, as we recognise on this side of the House, for a balance between what might be a free-for-all in enterprise bargaining in terms of a laissez-faire approach. But the emphasis on protection of employee interests has been very largely at the expense of employer interests and, ultimately, it is the employers who actually provide the jobs. You can only go on for so long biting the hand that feeds you before you realise that that will not work and that, indeed, it is not working. The fact that it is not working is reflected in the high levels of unemployment that we have had in recent years. Despite the very best attempts of the government to disguise that fact, clearly unemployment is on the rise again, even though the government has thrown millions of dollars at the problem by putting people onto all sorts of training schemes and giving them these new work opportunities, and so on. These are basically for the short term, to get them into a situation where they are at least not ostensibly unemployed. But the level of MC 1404 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 unemployment and underemployment in this country is huge. Realistically, taking the total level of unemployment and underemployment, we are probably looking at a figure closer to 15, 16 or even 20 per cent of the Australian work force, rather than the eight or so per cent that the official figures actually divulge. The unfair dismissal legislation which we dealt with in the parliament yesterday-which the minister claimed was an improvement on a good system but which, in fact, was only a minor improvement on a very bad system-really does not help us at all to overcome these problems. That effort alone has been another example of the incapacity of the Labor Party to handle the situation that exists. There is a lot more that could be said about this report. But the bottom line, in my view, is that it demonstrates a success in quantitative terms and not qualitative terms. I really fear that this government, as it has demonstrated over the past 12 years, has a total incapacity to move Australia as the times demand. theText: We have not been in a recession since 1983, and apart from the pilots'Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1405 Mr Barry Jones-There was very little economic structural change. frequently in the House during question time. If you compare the economy in those years with the economy now, it certainly speaks volumes. We also heard about the cosy relationship between the Labor Party and the trade union movement. We do not hear much from the other side about the cosy relationship between business and the Liberal Party. Where do they get their funds from at election times? We have only got to look at health policy, where one of the most predatory and greedy trade unions-if I can stretch the term-the AMA, virtually write the coalition's health policy. Enterprise bargaining in Australia discusses progress in enterprise bargaining. Our enterprise bargaining system has a legislative background. The Industrial Relations Reform Act came into effect on 30 March last year. The act was designed to encourage enterprise bargaining, while providing guarantees to ensure that employees are treated fairly and cannot be disadvantaged by bargaining. That is in direct contrast with the opposition policies. We keep hearing that there are too many restrictions, legislative and otherwise, on enterprise bargaining. Those restrictions are there for a very good reason: to protect workers and ensure that people are not disadvantaged by bargains which are struck. In relation to the award system, the main elements of the legislation are: employees are protected by awards that set fair and enforceable minimum wages and conditions of employment that are maintained at a relevant level; the award safety net is strengthened by guaranteeing access for all workers to minimum entitlements relating to minimum wages; there is equal remuneration of work for equal value; there are conditions relating to termination of employment, including unfair dismissal-we hear a lot about that from the opposition-and there is the right to 12 months unpaid parental leave. I do not think that any employer in this country has anything to fear. Any fair, sincere employer who follows due process has nothing to fear from unfair dismissal legislation. We have had so much hype and nonsense from the opposition, clearly for electoral reasons. Their scaremongering over this legislation seeks to alarm employers and to deter them from employing people. It is one of the most disgraceful disinformation campaigns I have seen. Nobody has anything to fear from due process. I am familiar with due process as it has been practised in the public sector over a long period of time. People should not be dismissed unfairly. They should be dismissed if they are not performing or if they do something wrong, such as stealing money. There are processes to allow that to happen. But to protest about the existence of unfair dismissal legislation is farcical. The legislation includes minimum entitlements giving effect to International Labour Organisation and UN conventions. Other elements seek to prevent and eliminate discrimination on the basis of race, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability-I do not like the term 'mental disability' as it appears in the legislation; it should be intellectual or psychiatric disability-marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin. These are basic equal opportunity provisions. The Industrial Relations Commission is also required to take account of ILO Convention 156 in performing its functions. In the bargaining stream the act provides for two types of enterprise agreements: certified agreements which are negotiated between employers and unions, and enterprise flexibility

I remind opposition members that I have not always followed the official government line on enterprise bargaining. Nor, for that matter, am I always in agreement with the official trade union line on enterprise bargaining. I was previously an active trade unionist in the public sector, and I recall that in the early 1990s, when enterprise bargaining was first on the agenda and debated, that there were many of us-particularly in the public sector, but right across the union movement-who were concerned about the likely effects of enterprise bargaining. I recall writing an article, which I circulated within my union, in which I expressed concerns about enterprise bargaining, particularly as it related to the public sector. I believed then that enterprise bargaining was a by-product of the economic rationalist culture that unfortunately seemed to dominate the government, and particularly central departments like Treasury, Finance and Industrial Relations. It also had its adherents, unfortunately, amongst the senior ranks of the ACTU and amongst many senior union officials around the country. I believed that enterprise bargaining had the potential to enable unionists and workers to be divided into bite sized chunks to make it easier for employers in the negotiating process. That came about because of the removal of the centralised wage fixing system, which a lot of us had seen as a safety net in itself over the years. Indeed, as this report recognises, there were fears that groups such as women, migrants, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, et cetera, could be disadvantaged through enterprise bargaining. I found it ironic that this was happening in an era when the trade union movement was going through huge structural reform. This involved amalgamations and the formation of megaunions, much of which was for reasons of efficiency. I agreed with most of the amalgamations although some of them have gone a tad too far now with these huge super-unions within which the rank and file tend to think they get lost. There are some problems with the extent to which amalgamations have gone but basically I agree with the philosophy of amalgamation of the myriad of unions that we had. I found it ironic that on the one hand you had an amalgamation of unions and on the other hand you had a push to divide up workers into enterprise groups for the purposes of bargaining. Nevertheless, it was recognised amongst my colleagues in the public sector that enterprise bargaining was here and that those who wanted to oppose enterprise bargaining had lost the battle. I guess where the debate hotted up in the public sector was on the issue of agency bargaining. Instead of the APS being the enterprise for enterprise bargaining, there was concern that we were going to be broken up into different agencies. It was feared that workers in different government departments would be subject to different bargains and different wage outcomes, et cetera. However, I am pleased to say that I have recently been informed that common sense has prevailed in the public sector for basic wages and conditions negotiations. The APS is to be the agency and we will not have differential wage outcomes for public servants in different government departments. I think that would have been a bit of a farce. Having made a few comments and having expressed my reservations when I was in the union movement about enterprise bargaining, I would have to say that at least under Labor's system of enterprise bargaining there are some safeguards in place, unlike what we could expect from a coalition government, as we have seen in various states around Australia. Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITrEE MC 1407 I tum to the report. It points out quite clearly a number of messages. It points out that the extra protection for employees introduced through our legislation is having a positive effect and that bargaining under our federal system is fairer for employees as compared with other forms of agreements, particularly those put in place by state conservative governments. New federal agreements are more likely to reward employees for putting in extra hours and effort. Employees in workplaces with new federal agreements were least likely to report an increase in working hours but, where hours had gone up, employees were more likely than others to have also received an increase in weekly pay. That is, they were more likely to get a fair deal in the work effort bargain. Compared with other forms of agreements, new federal agreements were more likely to result in wage increases for all employees. More employees in workplaces with new federal agreements, 63 per cent, had received a wage increase in the previous 12 months than had employees in other types of workplaces with other types of agreements. Compared with other types of agreements, new federal agreements were more likely to be seen by women and part-time workers as giving them a fair chance to have a say in workplace bargaining. In workplaces with new federal agreements, women said that they were consulted just as often as men were, but in workplaces under other types of agreements women were considerably less likely than men to have been consulted about bargaining and were less likely to say that they had had a fair chance to have a say in enterprise bargaining. Also, compared with other agreements, federal agreements were more likely to be seen by women and part-timers as making them better off. The report goes on to some other very important areas. The second key message from the report is that under the federal system these agreements are also delivering better coverage and that, because of the way in which the federal government industrial relations framework protects employees, workers feel more confident about entering into agreements. Consequently, there is a significant growth in enterprise and workplace agreements, particularly in the federal industrial relations system and in the services sector. The take-up rate in the federal jurisdiction accelerated after the reform act took effect. There were over 1,450 new federal agreements formalised in the reporting period, more than doubling the rate of agreement making of the pre-reform act period. The majority of new federal agreements, that is, 76 per cent of those agreements, came from the private sector. We now have about 5,500 agreements formalised, covering 58 per cent of federal award covered employees. No wonder people are flocking from state awards to federal awards, particularly in Victoria. The third key message is that these agreements are helping to encourage the spread of enterprise bargaining and helping to deliver good economic results. There is plenty of evidence of that around the country. We hear a lot from the other side and from the conservative media that these enterprise agreements will cause more industrial disputes. That is clearly wrong. As I said before, I cannot remember a significant federal industrial dispute since 1983. Once again, I think there is an element of scaremongering in that. The enterprise bargaining report is an interesting report. Although there are some sobering messages in it, which I do not have time to go into, at least under our system workers will be far better off than under the coalition, and they well know it. speaker: Mr Sinclair (New England) (11.32 A.m.)
theText: It is worthwhile having a report on enterpriseMC 1408 MAIN COMMlITEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 brought to wage negotiation. Whether or not the report reflects what it should in terms of an analysis of the state of play at the workface-I am not sure whether it is the work force or the workface, because this would seem to me to exercise a number of views with respect to employees and wage conditions-it seems to say very little about public interest and what the impact has been on the overall state of industry. Nor does it state the extent to which, as a result of enterprise bargaining and the Labor Party's changes to industrial relations, there is a better prospect for those who are unemployed getting a job, those who are in search of part-time jobs receiving part-time employment or those who are on welfare receiving some opportunity of getting into the work force. The report says a great deal about a narrow subject and says nothing at all about a lot of the matters that we, as parliamentarians, should address. Fundamentally it does represent, yet again, something of the interface between the Labor Party and the trade union movement. It is sad for the Labor Party's sake, rather than for anybody else's sake, that they have not been able to look beyond that relationship. It is demonstrable, with a large number of employees voting with their feet by leaving the trade union movement, that there are increasingly persons who are not being represented by the relationship between the trade unions and the Labor Party, who traditionally would have seen their natural political alignment with that political force. The report tells a great deal about a narrow part of the subject but very little about where we are going. When I look at it, it makes me wonder whether there are not still fundamental problems in enterprise bargaining, although, from the perspective of the coalition, it is a far better means of negotiating wages and conditions than now exists. The changes that the Labor Party has introduced are still too narrow. There is too little flexibility and we need to look very carefully at what are the minimal conditions which need to be provided. I do not see that providing an arbitrary role for the trade union movement in negotiations, after an enterprise agreement has been negotiated and before ratification is in any way advancing the cause of good relations and harmony in the workplace. Nor does it go towards addressing the overall question of whether or not enterprise bargaining is a better way to achieve productivity in industry. Fundamentally, the problem we have in Australia is that we have a lot of unemployed. What the government fails to understand is that enterprise bargaining should be looking both at the way by which you can employ people and people can be employed to the mutual advantage of each and, at the same time, at how you can make the whole of the workplace more effective and more productive and you can get more jobs. The more complications and the more difficulties there are in aspects of your industrial relations administration, the harder it is, particularly for small business employers, to employ people. There has been a good deal of discussion in the parliament of the degree to which the unfair dismissal provisions now apply and how people can be dismissed-whether or not they are able, in a small business, to be dismissed on the grounds of a person's unsatisfactory behaviour or aspects related to personal incompatibility. All these complications make it harder and harder for small business to employ people and I do not believe that in the rigidity of enterprise bargaining, as it is now structured under part VIB of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, there is sufficient flexibility to address that question with the overall public good in mind. The other aspect that worries me is whether or not, in the overall relationship between the parties, there is enough treatment given to labour on-costs. If we are looking at one of the real Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1409 disincentives against employment today, it is not how much an employee receives but how much his particular place costs the employer and, consequently, the extent to which that person is far more expensive to the employer than immediately is apparent. The total labour package is far more than the wage paid to the employees. As we have seen in international comparisons, in many instances Australian workers are not overpaid, but the labour on-costs are excessive and consequently there are major difficulties. Another problem that I see in the report is that that sector of the community that you, Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, and I represent, the rural community, does not have as much of a part in enterprise bargaining as larger corporations. To my mind, it has always been a problem with Labor that they have looked at big business and big unions as being a way by which big government can flourish and they can flourish with it. In rural Australia it is the individual rather than collective bargaining force that is so often important. It seemed to me, when enterprise bargaining was first mooted, that there was a significant advantage in our being able to develop the concept of being able to once again relate the person who is in charge of a business to the person who is employed in the business, and come out with a negotiated arrangement which takes account of the whole framework within which they are employed. In rural Australia, so often the conditions vary from region to region, state to state and property to property. Enterprise bargaining tends to take account of the power of a collective trade union, so that if you are looking at award conditions affecting the shearing industry, for example, they are not negotiable between an individual who operates his or her own woolshed and the people who work in that shed; they are negotiated on a much wider basis. In that climate, I do not know that you necessarily provide the conditions that are best suited to the particular enterprise. It is for that reason again that I have reservations about the present structure of enterprise bargaining within the presently worded part VIB. It is important that there be enormous flexibility in workplace arrangements. It is important not to continue the old division that used to exist. It ensured that, where there were negotiations around the terms and conditions of employment, they seemed to take place between an industrial relations officer of a company and a trade union official. I felt they were unsatisfactory. It is far better having an arrangement where the people are involved in the workplace and the person who owns the business or is managing the business can actually talk to the people who are on the work floor. Unless you can achieve that, too often the conditions do not relate to a particular enterprise. That is all reflected in the fact that, in this report, there is a good deal of comment about the impact of part VIB, on employees and on particular minority groups, all of whom are significant and all of whom are important. There is no real consideration of the impact of part VIB on employment generally or its impact on employers or productivity. It tends to focus on the old battleground of two classes, and I suggest that these are now archaic. It is no longer just a matter of employer and employee. It is a matter of public good and public benefit and productivity and how to deal with the unemployed. It is matter of getting people back into the work force, albeit perhaps under different terms and conditions. These things are important. Above all, when looking at this report, it has to be remembered that there are still about one million Australians out of work, including people on various make work programs. A very large percentage of the total work force is totally excluded from enterprise bargaining. Nothing in enterprise bargaining, in this report and in the legislation that Labor has framed, provides the opportunity for people out of work to get back into the work force. Unless it identifies MC 1410 MAIN COMMITI'EE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 what it will do for business to improve our productivity, to make us more competitive-with total quality management and all these other facets of competition-unfortunately, enterprise bargaining is going to form only a small part of the total analysis of how a particular enterprise works and its efficiency. I tum briefly to the report to address a couple of aspects. Page xxxi of the summary headed 'The impact of part VIB agreements on employees' mentions that the average annual wage increase of employees covered by part VIB of the agreement was in the order of four per cent. It suggests that is a fairly significant achievement. To my mind, one of the difficulties with that is that it is not just in wage increases that one should assess the benefits to an enterprise. I think there are all sorts of other facets which are really important-for instance, the likelihood of the job being a permanent job; the extent to which the workplace itself is a better workplace than it was before; the extent to which the person's take home pay is increased. A wage increase, more often than not under our PAYE system-the taxation applied by the Labor government-means that a person's pay is significantly different from the amount the person puts in his pocket at the end of the week, the fortnight or the month. For that reason, the measure of comparison is not necessarily right. On page 73 of the main report, 3.3, 'Union involvement in enterprise flexibility agreements', is another one of the real downsides. If there is a negotiated agreement without the union initially being involved, the unions are automatically given, under this sell-out between the government and the ACTU, a right to intervene. I know there are circumstances where employees may be disadvantaged by the relative bargaining strength they exercise against management and the employer, and it is important that that be recognised. But it does not apply universally and, too often, on the basis of a negotiated arrangement, there has not been full account taken of the opportunity of a particular business to stay in business. If the union has the capacity to intervene in every instance, it does not look at the capacity of the business to survive or at the overall conditions within that particular business place to the same degree that it looks at whether or not its own members or the extended membership is advantaged or disadvantaged by that particular agreement. I am afraid that self-interest by the trade union movement, in many instances, has meant that its membership has suffered. I mentioned page 205, 'Impact on employees-overview', when I was talking about the lack of matters that are identified within the report. In my mind, it is not just a matter of the impact on employees that is important. I think you have got to look at a far wider subject, and I regret that has not been taken up anywhere in the report. Finally, looking at the section headed 'Management and unions', I think we have to understand that it is not just a matter of relative bargaining skills; it is a matter of relative advantage. I do not think relative advantage necessarily flows from the way in which this report has been addressed. On page 298 in section 6.9, there is a comment I just want to refer to before I close. The second paragraph says: While the report has highlighted some areas that will need to be addressed in future reports, particularly issues for non-English speaking background employees, provisions under Part VIB appear to have also generally promoted fairer outcomes for employees than might otherwise have been the case. I think that shows that, if we had a proper enterprise bargaining system without the undue restraints which Labor has imposed on it, the concept is right. Unfortunately, I do not believe that what has been introduced under part VIB by the present Labor administration is right. Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1411 That that is so is illustrated by the intervention of the federal government in a particular enterprise bargaining arrangement I noted in the paper yesterday, where I understand a work force have decided that they are no longer going to take sick leave and have negotiated a wage increase in order to compensate for it. They have done it on a totally fair and open-minded basis; they have done it to get more pay; and now the federal government is intervening to disrupt that enterprise arrangement. I do not think that is fair. I do not think it is desirable. I think it illustrates, yet again, the failure of enterprise bargaining under the Labor structured changes to industrial relations legislation. speaker, the member for New England( Mr Sinclair), dealt with. One was that he said people were leaving their trade unions. That is not correct. People may not be joining trade unions, but that is because of a different work situation in Australia with different situations and different ways of working, the increase in part-time and casual work and a whole change in the industrial work force of the country. The change has resulted in less manufacturing employment and a move to a whole range of different jobs which have never traditionally involved organised labour. That is basically why there has been a decline in union membership in the country. It is very interesting that the member for New England raised issues about shearing sheds and said that we could have different rates from one shearing shed to another. That would be a very interesting concept, with one shearer shearing alongside another shearer and one being paid more than another. It is a different matter when it is a learner and a shearer. But it will be a very interesting time if different rates are introduced into the country, between one shed and another, and there will be a very interesting argument when the shearers might all live 500 miles away and we are relating it to the actual negotiated position on a particular shed. I find that a pretty fascinating position. It basically comes down to an individual bargain and an individual contract being struck on the job. It will be an interesting time if we ever get to that in Australia. That also brings me to the point that I believe you get to the lowest common denominator with that sort of approach. That is, one contractor applies for a contract and, as that contractor winds back his cost structure, the lowest he can wind back, the further down he can get the labour component, the better chance he has of getting that contract. Therefore, you get the lowest common denominator in wages coming in to the individual and you get that through all sorts of industries in this country. It would lead to a very low paid work force without very much dignity at all. The first annual report, Enterprise bargaining in Australia, is a comprehensive review of the results of developments in enterprise bargaining at the workplace level. It is required under the Industrial Relations Act. This part of the act was originally designed to encourage enterprise bargaining while providing guarantees to ensure that employees are treated fairly and cannot be disadvantaged by bargaining. That is the crunch of this debate and what the previous speaker was talking about, because those on the other side of the House really are about making sure there is not any disadvantage rule-that somebody can go down as low as the employer can drive them. The further down they can get you the better the opportunity. That will be the name of the game; that will be what enterprise bargaining is about. It is about bargaining someone's wages and conditions
