theText: I will just deal with a couple of points that the previousMC 1412 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 as low as possible so the employer can win a contract or can gain some other advantage in the marketplace. In reforming industrial relations in Australia, this government put a strong emphasis on protecting the interests of employees. Right through the restructuring of industry which this government has tackled and has had to take on, at times there have certainly been great difficulties in some of those approaches but at least there has been an opportunity from this government's point of view to give support to the interests of employees. That has of course been coming from a Labor government. In addition to the importance of equity in its own right, adequate protections were seen as encouraging the participation of employees in bargaining. If we get into the enterprise itself, where bargaining is taking place, we want to get people to take up the opportunity to discuss bargaining with an employer. At issue here are the nature of employee safeguards, the effect of the agreements on wages and conditions, and employees' own assessments of the impact of change and bargaining on their working lives. I see that the report deals with some of that and I see that the less consultation shown by employees, the worse off they feel-the more they feel they are being discriminated against or they have lost out on the bargaining process. The more consultation, the more involvement they have, the better off they certainly feel about gaining a benefit from the bargain. In the federal scheme there are several legislative tests or requirements in addition to the consultation requirement designed for a more effective and fairer outcome. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission must be satisfied that there are tests that have been met in order for a new federal agreement to be certified or approved. The no disadvantage test requires the AIRC to be satisfied that an agreement does not, in relation to its terms and conditions of employment, disadvantage the employees whom it covers. This means that the AIRC will not approve an agreement which results in a reduction of employees' entitlements and protections taken as a whole, unless the AIRC considers that such reduction is not contrary to the public interest. In order to have access to agreements, employees' terms and conditions of employment must be covered by an award. The annual report for 1994 shows that there have been several significant gains with growth in enterprise and work place agreements, particularly in the federal industrial relations scheme and in the service sector, with bargaining spreading across a large range of industries to cover a majority of employees right throughout the federal scheme. The report did identify some concerns and these are bound to occur in this system and in any scheme that is starting up. These include some lack of skills and resources for agreement making; improvement in workplace relations, women and other groups and bargaining; and the commitment of those involved-that is, people committed to proper bargaining rather than not bargaining from one side to another or bargaining one down because one is stronger than another, or one not having the skills or the information to bargain fairly. While the Labor government is trying to iron out some of these problems and to develop better relations between employers and employees, I do not see very much progress from the other side at alL The other side continues with the argument to get rid of the 'no disadvantage' rule so that it can drive conditions and wages down. The other side of the House is about opening up the system so that a bargain can be driven for the lowest possible wages in this Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1413 country. The other side will continue to do so and this is the policy it will take to the next election. This policy comes from the support of the other side of the House for individual contracts. The bottom line of the other side of the House in its bargaining position will be to have people sign individual contracts. As somebody walks onto a work site, they will be asked to 'sign here'. Suddenly, the worker will find himself or herself working alongside somebody who is doing exactly the same work but who is being paid twice as much or a third as much again as the worker is being paid merely because he has been there a bit longer or there has been another agreement reached and his contract does not come up for renewal again. This is hardly a situation for industrial harmony or for getting people to work together to improve productivity. In the long term, it is a recipe for suspicion, jealousy and disruption. The quality of work is sure to fall and the situation will act as a disincentive for people in the workplace to work as a team. There will be no enthusiastic feeling for work and no pride in being rewarded for helping to make the company successful in any way. Desperate people will sign on for the sake of getting a job; that is what other people play on and have always played on. But, if people cannot meet their basic commitments in life-housing, food and transport-they will become the working poor of Australia and they will be forced into having to survive with these minimal conditions and wages. It may be thought that it is great for the bosses to control conditions, but, if the other side of the House has its way, we will going back to other eras of our history, with charities being forced to cope with more and more handouts and with people not being able to make ends meet. There needs to be a safety net and there needs to be a means by which people can ensure that they are not used and abused by the bad employers. In an adjournment speech recently, the honourable member for Grey( Mr Wakelin) talked about how small business will pick up all the unemployed people in Australia. The member for Grey quoted somebody-he said that it is an old statement-in saying that there are 700,000 small businesses and that, if they all employ one new person, Australia will do away with the unemployment issue. It is such a naive view to think that it is possible for all small businesses to take on another individual. As this report on enterprise bargaining shows, there is a great deal of enterprise bargaining coming into play. There have been agreements reached during which everybody concerned has shown goodwill and where pluses for both sides have occurred. Where there is goodwill and a system of not disadvantaging employees, through enterprise bargaining major gains can be made in productivity and profitability and, therefore, everybody involved with the enterprise is better off. But the enterprise has to be based on goodwill and the debate and the bargaining have to be fair and reasonable. However, to achieve this situation, you need some rules in place so that people are not disadvantaged. The no-disadvantage rule is of major importance to the working people of Australia. I also believe the report shows the transparent and open approach that this government has to industrial relations. People can see where we are and what we are doing, as opposed to those on the other side, who are continuing not to announce their full policy or tell working people of Australia what they could expect under those on that side of the House if they were in government. I think that is a very dishonest position. That is certainly a position that I will be pointing out to most of the workers around my electorate in Tasmania-that the noMC 1414 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 disadvantage rule will certainly disappear, that individual contracts will be the go under a government from the other side and that people will certainly be much worse off. I commend the report to the House. (Time expired) about previous speakers in this debate on enterprise bargaining. Firstly, there have been some comments about unions and how the Liberal Party is anti-union, how we want to bash the unions and how they are a very separate enterprise. In fact, the Australian Labor Party is the political arm of the union movement. We all know that and I think it is time that we actually started admitting that in this place. The union movement, we all know, started up a hundred years ago or thereabouts and established its own political arm called the ALP. To question that, one has to look at the way that they are funded. They are funded in a lot of ways by government grants. If we look at the amount of donations the unions pay back to the ALP, being the lay party, one then thinks there must be some sort of collusion here, or alleged collusion, between the union movement and the ALP, using taxpayers' funds. But also we can look at the members of parliament on the ALP side who are former members of unions. The current president of the ACTU is about to join the parliament, if he is successful in the next election; we have Minister Crean, the member for Hotham, who is a former president of the ACTU; and the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was a member of the ACTU as president. Although we have not put our IR policy into the workplace or into the political environment yet, already the president-elect, Ms Jennie George, is saying, 'We are not going to be working with the Liberal movement.' There has been some suggestion about union disputation reducing over the period of the ALP government. Of course it would be. Why would they want to have a dispute with their own party? That is the reason why there is no union disputation during this period of ALP government, because they in fact run the government themselves, so why look bad? It is also interesting to note that the member who just spoke, the member for Lyons( Mr Adams), talked about individual contracts. speaker: Mr Richard Evans
theText: I am very pleased to join the discussion today on the 1994 annualWednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1415 Australian industrial relations is heading. It seems that the beneficiaries of this course of New Age IR policies are in fact big business, big unions and those involved in the industry club of IR. Small businesses, employees of small businesses, non-English speaking migrants and, in many cases, women and part-time workers are not the beneficiaries. The warm and fuzzy feelings given to us by the many who support the current arrangements are simply hollow rhetoric based upon expediency of politics, for it seems that the word 'human' has been taken out of the new IR regime. No longer do we have 'human' resources and 'human' relationships, so important in the modem workplace. Rather, we now have a desire to seek greater return on the invested dollar. Gone is the need for enterprises to base their operations on providing a service to the market and to the many stakeholders-not shareholders, but stakeholders-associated with an enterprise, and thus to contribute to the development of a healthy community. What we now have is an industry basing itself on financial profits. There is nothing wrong with the notion of basing yourself on profit, as long as it is in direct proportion to the vital development of the greater community; but, now, these enterprises are mostly seeing their employees as figures on a balance sheet. In human terms, enterprise bargaining has focused enterprises on value for money and it has ignored the greater importance of humanising an enterprise. There are exceptions to the rule on any issue, and some enterprises are empowering their staff; yet, so often, enterprises are fixated on dollars rather than on people. It is important to reflect upon the changes that our world has been facing over the last 20 or so years. We are in the grip of a major crisis of change, a transitional period. We are going from the industrial age into the information or technology age. Two hundred years ago, we went through a similar period of transition. It was called the Industrial Revolution and it lasted for about 50 years and was a period of great crisis where we went from the agricultural age into the industrial age. There were people who saw the opportunity within crisis-since crisis can offer either danger or. opportunity-and there were countries, companies and organisations that saw the opportunity to go into the industrial age at a rapid rate of knots and to develop in that way-America and England being two good examples. A good example of the countries that wanted to hang on to their old agricultural ways and wanted to hang on to their old agricultural structures would be the countries of eastern Europe. Moving forward 200 years, we are now going through another period of transition which is really challenging everything in our society. We are challenged in our community, our education system, the way we do things, and everything that we do-just as happened 200 years ago in the Industrial Revolution. What we are challenged to do is to move from the industrial age into the information age or the technology age. We are finding, of course, that the structures of management are breaking down. People are trying to make the hierarchical pyramid structure that we had in the industrial age flatter and meaner. Of course, that is not working. What is working is a network structure where you have independent work modules who are empowered for their own decision making capabilities and who can operate independently with a common vision in mind. The key to this networking and empowering of industry, companies and enterprises is in fact a reduced and relaxed industrial relations systems. But what we see is a more structured approach. Even the report says, on page xxxiv, 'Many of the changes that were observed, for better or worse, in Australian work places were changes that would have occurred anyway.' MC 1416 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 We have a system of enterprise bargaining still based upon the industrial age; and, although industry and enterprises are crying out for some change, we are not really seeing any change. We are seeing a continuation of industrial age thinking, driven by industrial age managers and supported by industrial age unions.We do not see New Age thinking which empowers employees to participate in decision making and work strategies. As an example of that, page xxxv of the summary in Enterprise bargaining in Australia says: Evidence from employees on workplace cooperation suggests that, both for workplaces with Part VIB agreements and for non-VIB workplaces, there remained considerable scope for improvement of workplace relations. A large part of the responsibility for this is in the hands of management. A weak performance by management, in both Part VIB and non-VIB workplaces in improving information flows and employee participation in decision-making, in the context of growing calls on employees to increase effort or work under great stress, and increased pressure on their ability to balance work and family lives, is a major reason why there were not more employees expressing the view that they had been made better off as a result of workplace bargaining. It is largely up to managementindustrial age management, by the sound of thisto find better ways of dealing with this collection of issues. Where it does not, it may find that employee willingness to continue the process of negotiation and change at the workplace-level may wane ... I tend to agree with that summary, because I do not think the actual enterprise bargaining system is working, for the reason that the people involved-whether they be big business, big unions, managers, unionists or whatever they might be-are still tied up in the notion of industrial age thinking and have not moved forward into the information age. We see that the very authors of the report are concerned about the process. Another example of the IR system not yet working effectively is the statement of the authors that it was 'less likely to provide for different rates of pay rises for employees covered by agreements'. In other words, if you are the best worker in an enterprise, you will get paid exactly the same amount of money as the worse worker in an enterprise. I, as an individual who wants choice in an enterprise, suggest that is unfair. Any fair-thinking unionist would agree with me, I think. However, they are stuck in the industrial age thinking, and they say, 'Lowest common denominator: let's pay everyone the same and let's forget about paying or rewarding people who want to put in.' In other words, if an employee wants to assume the rights offered by an employer, and accepts the responsibility of putting effort into their work, why should the employee be discriminated against? Enterprise bargaining, in fact, is discriminating against those employees who want to put the effort in and increase the opportunity of potential income increases. This is but one of the examples of where the enterprise bargaining system is letting down employees who have confidence-great confidence-in their own abilities, and have to accept this notion of lowest common denominator pay. Why should someone who wants to put the effort in have to accept the lowest level? It says here, according to the authors, that it is less likely to provide different rates of pay for employees covered by agreements. Why can the better employees not get paid more? I support the principles of enterprise bargaining. However, I believe that there is much to do within the whole area of workplace reform. One of the areas that needs reforming is the understanding that we are out of the industrial age and we are moving into empowering Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMlITEE MC 1417 employees in the decision making process. We have to accept that. I have yet to see thatwanting to move away from the industrial age, into the information and technology age-from major enterprises, I have yet to see that from major management organisations, and I have yet to see that from major unions. A very good example of the reason the unions are suffering in this area is their membership downfall. They are not getting into the service industries which are servicing the information age. All the commentators say there should be some change in workplace reform. All the practitioners say there should be some change. Employees have stated, in this report, that they want to do more and they are capable of doing more. Yet the IR club is wallowing in a scheme which is old-world. It is still just wanting to project the scheme that it has developed over many years, which was structured well for the industrial age but is not appropriate for the information age or for individual networking modules with individual decision making capacity and strategies. It is not appropriate for any of that at all. For the sake of a profitable future for our young people who are suffering under the policies of the government, because they are not getting employed in our industries, we need to urgently address these issues and look at enterprise bargaining. Perhaps the IR clubs should consider that there are things other than paying on the lowest common denominator and that we should be looking at rewarding those who want to put the effort in. comments on the report Enterprise bargaining in Australia. It is an issue that I, as a former union official in the service sector, have some considerable interest in. I also have some interest in the structural changes that are going on in our economy which are, amongst other things, making things fairly difficult for unions in many sectors. They are also leading to changes in how wage fixing occurs, how bargaining over pay and conditions is conducted and associated issues. Let me go through some of the main findings of the report. Firstly, enterprise bargaining in the federal system is now pretty widespread and it has become entrenched throughout the majority of workplaces covered by federal awards. Secondly, the extent of this coverage is significantly greater than has been the case within the state award systems that have enterprise bargaining as an adjunct. Thirdly, enterprise bargaining in the federal system has produced better outcomes, both with respect to pay and remuneration for employees and with respect to productivity and efficiency improvements for employers, than equivalents in the state systems. Fourthly, enterprise bargaining is better accepted by workers and unionists in the federal system than it is in the equivalent state systems. Fifthly, there are significant areas of the service sector that are significantly less permeated by enterprise bargaining than the remainder of the work force or industry. This is partly because of the fact that most of these areas tend to be predominantly covered by state industrial relations systems rather than by the federal system, although that is not exclusively the case. Finally, enterprise flexibility agreements--enterprise bargains for non-unionists-have, to date, spread only in a fairly limited way. Those are probably the major themes that I extract from the report. There is certainly a lot of very interesting data in the report. I commend the report to the parliament as a worthwhile exercise in seeking to understand the early stages of a new and very different industrial relations system in this country. Perhaps some of the more interesting aspects of the report relate to the findings on the perceptions of workers affected by enterprise bargaining, and some

speaker: Mr Tanner (Melbourne) (12.16 P.m.)
theText: I welcome the opportunity to make someMC 1418 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 of their attitudes on what enterprise bargaining has meant for them. Surprisingly enough, it is not all positive. Given my own experience with enterprise bargaining as a trade union official, predominantly with people for whom enterprise bargaining was fairly difficult, that does not come as a great surprise. There are a variety of statistics in the report. For example, the report estimates that at the end of 1994 roughly 1.46 million workers, or 57 per cent of employees, covered by federal awards are covered by enterprise bargains. I think it is very much a tribute to the efforts of those involved in both designing and managing the new system, including the minister, that enterprise bargaining has managed to spread to that number of people that quickly. Agreements are more common, according to these statistics, in the larger, more heavily unionised parts of the economy and in the public sector, both of which should come as no surprise. Reverting to my comments earlier about the extent to which there are negative responses to enterprise bargaining from workers, approximately one-third of workers surveyed indicated that in their view, in the enterprise bargains that they were now subject to, they had not had a fair chance to have a say in the process of determining their own pay and conditions through the enterprise bargaining process. That is an issue that requires a fair bit more examination. It certainly is a disturbing conclusion, one that my own experience suggests is not a great surprise. It is important for us to understand where enterprise bargaining has come from and why it is that we are seeing a decentralisation of the industrial relations process in Australia now. There is a tendency amongst some in the union movement to regard this as some sort of New Right plot, yet another sell-out by a devious Labor government or other such epithets. This is a fairly superficial analysis. Really, enterprise bargaining has emerged as a product of structural economic change in our society and, in essence, three critical and interrelated factors. The first of these is diversification in the production process. The main award that I used to deal with as a union official-originally the commercial clerks award and subsequently the clerical and administrative employees award--covered somewhere between 150,000 and 200,000 workers in the state of Victoria, ranging from the smallest enterprise up to BHP head office. Back in the forties, when that award and others were probably in their heyday, the notion that you could have a single document setting out in effect a comprehensive set of terms and conditions, a comprehensive employment contract covering that number of people working across an incredibly diverse range of enterprises, had some merit. These days, with the types of activities being performed by office workers, the types of skills that they are being asked to employ and the demands being placed upon them by their employers, the needs of their employers are infinitely more diverse than they were back in the forties and fifties. It is becoming increasingly difficult to have that sort of broad, catch-all award covering such a diverse array of enterprises and such a vast number of people, because of the intrinsic diversification that is going on in the workplace within the production process. For customised work arrangements that are emerging, we are inevitably going to need more customised employment contract arrangements. That is the first of the three influences that have produced enterprise bargaining and will produce further change. The second of these influences is internationalisation. What that has done is to put enormous pressure on Australian industry, particularly trade exposed industry, to get rid of entrenched, inefficient work practices, demarcations and a variety of other things. Essentially, they have been allowed to develop and remain because of the protected status of much of Australian Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITI'EE MC 1419 industry for many years. With exposure to international competition and a much harsher international environment putting a lot of pressure on many Australian companies, the heat has understandably gone on many of these practices. However glibly people may look at these things and decide that they should be eliminated, it is not easy to do so when they actually get down to the practical grassroots problems, when they are facing a given situation in the workplace with a group of workers with established arrangements, established entitlements, a given level of morale and commitment to the firm. It is not easy to change these things. Having been part of it in a number of areas, I understand this only too well. The third factor which has driven enterprise bargaining has been the growing gap in pay that the market is offering to people according to their skills so that those with greater skills and greater flexibility and adaptability are increasingly attracting a higher and higher premium for those skills. The old centralised system, including paid rates awards, has been cracking under the strain of that increasing market pressure for higher pay for higher skilled workers. That in itself is a problem for government and a problem for the solidarity of our society, and has to be tacked in other ways. There are, however, serious problems with enterprise bargaining and I would like to comment on just some of them. The first and most obvious is that the impact of enterprise bargaining on industrially weaker workers, such as those I generally represented as a union official, can be quite adverse. This is an understandable consequence of a more market based system of wage determination. Particular groups in the work force, such as women workers who tend to occupy less industrially powerful positions, casual and part-time workers, people from a non-English speaking background, people with lower skills or very broad generic skills that are easily replaceable, lack bargaining power and lack muscle. If there is a system such as enterprise bargaining that is predominantly based on muscle, then inevitably those people are going to suffer relative to others. Blue-collar workers, particularly the skilled male blue-collar workers in many parts of industry, have a fair bit to trade in the game of enterprise bargaining. They have the ability to do deals and to back up their negotiating power with muscle to ensure that they get reasonable deals. Also, unlike many service workers, unlike many workers in some of the New Age areas that the honourable member for Cowan( Mr Richard Evans) referred to, their productivity is amenable to measurement. One of the great difficulties that my union had with enterprise bargaining was that, with the type of workers that we represented-office workers, often multi skilled, conducting a range of tasks according to what day it was and what was going on-it is very difficult to measure changes in their productivity. This is a problem which ultimately means that some people are going to benefit a lot more from enterprise bargaining than others. The experience that our union has had in many areas of enterprise bargaining has been that deals that we have ultimately been forced to accept have often included loss of very basic things such as tea breaks, people working unpaid hours, chronic understaffing being entrenched and a range of other things, whereas people with more muscle, on the shop floor, for example, have been able to do deals for similar increases in pay without the serious loss of conditions. I give a simple example with respect to the Ford Motor Company and the enterprise bargain where my union and the former ADSTE union were ultimately bludgeoned into accepting an enterprise bargain for a six per cent pay increase, which other unions, the blue-collar unions, also got for fairly limited trade-offs. The trade-offs that were ultimately forced out of our MC 1420 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 members were a shift to monthly pay, working three hours a week extra for no additional pay, and a variety of other more minor trade-offs. Our members voted three times against accepting this deal and opted to stay on their current wage rates if that was the deal but, ultimately, the company was so determined to force this change through, even though it was clearly detrimental to their work force, that by applying individual pressure, by engaging in union busting tactics, they were ultimately able to get enough of our members to agree individually so that eventually the resistance of the membership to this deal collapsed, and the outcome was fairly predictable. That is a fairly good illustration of the types of things that happen under enterprise bargaining. Those who have less industrial muscle, those who have less to trade off, are often going to end up with adverse outcomes. It is important to remember though that there is a significant difference between the position of the government and the labour movement position on these issues and that of the opposition. What the opposition is ultimately on about-and I think the honourable member for Cowan expressed it fairly well-is individual contracts. Although the government and the labour movement are moving towards a more decentralised system, ultimately because of the broader forces in the society and in the economy that I referred to before, there still is a collective basis of social equity underpinning the system through things like safety net increases, award protection and the like. The conservative parties would tear all this away. They are trimming, shifting and trying to pretend that they will not but there is no doubt that if they do get elected these things will not last very long. What they are about is redistribution from the industrially weak, from the economically weak, to the economically strong. Jobsback was a recipe to destroy the award system, to put in such farcical mechanisms as the employee advocate to try and undermine the role of independent trade unions and ultimately to move people in the work force onto individual contracts. The difference between the opposition and the Labor Party is that we support collectivism. We support collective social justice and not survival of the fittest. As I indicated, the honourable member for Cowan just put forward a very good exposition of a New Age version of survival of the fittest. Why should the employee who works a bit better not get paid more than the employee who in the subjective-and often flawed-judgment of the employer is not quite as good a worker. That is ultimately a recipe for social division. It is ultimately a recipe for inequality and it is in complete contrast to the sort of hypocritical cant that we heard yesterday from the honourable member for Kooyong( Mr Georgiou) and from various opposition members about the growing inequality in our society. On the one hand, they complain about that inequality but, on the other, they are seeking to put in place policies which will massively increase inequality and unfairness in our society. So enterprise bargaining does have some dangerous aspects to it which tend in that direction, but it is occurring for broad, structural economic reasons. The government has put in place protective safety net measures to ensure that those who are weakest economically and industrially are substantially protected in the new wage fixing system that we have. speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (12.31 P.m.)
theText: I am very pleased to join this debate in which we areWednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1421 that I was a little saddened to hear some of the rhetoric of the honourable member who has just completed speaking, the member for Melbourne ( Mr Tanner). in the Australia of 1995. What we should be seeking to do, as members of this place, is to encourage an industrial relations system which will deliver fairness, cooperation, productivity, flexibility and, indeed, an overall better result for Australia. The Minister for Industrial Relations ( Mr Brereton) could only be described as a hapless individual because he has come into the parliament on a number of occasions and brought in various industrial relations amendments and, time after time, he has been forced to return to the chamber because his amendments have been proved not to work. Enterprise bargaining is a very major reform in Australia. Unfortunately, the government has taken the coalition's terminology but has brought provisions into the law that have ensured that enterprise bargaining has simply not worked as it should. The Labor Party, of course, is heavily dependent on the trade union movement and heavily dependent on the trade union scare campaign at election times. One really ought to look at the comments made just after the 1993 election by the aspirant president of the ACTU, Jennie George, when she said: What the employers have got to understand is that we won the election in March and this billthat is referring to the industrial relations billis a payback for the commitments that were made by the government in the course of that election campaign. Really, what Jennie George was saying was that the government bribed the union movement, the government had to deliver, and the industrial relations bill which was introduced by the minister and which became law was a reward for the union movement. We all know that that reward has not worked and the minister has had to change the legislation over and over again. The report we are noting here this morning comprises almost 400 pages-399, in fact-and I must say that there really was no good news for the minister there. There was no real joy for him in the reaction which this report received throughout the Australian community. It is fairly clear that employers are not happy; it is very clear that many employees are not happy, including women. So while the minister has put the best gloss that he could on this report from his own perspective, he really has to accept that his approach to enterprise bargaining has not worked. One only has to look at the Financial Review on 21 August 1995 where a report points out: What has been hailed as one of Australia's major industrial relations reforms-the push for enterprise bargaining-is causing widespread dissatisfaction throughout the workforce, with a significant proportion reporting deteriorating job satisfaction, greater stress and reduced job security. The honourable member for Melbourne, who spoke previously, pointed out some of the problems that the work force sees in relation to the government's approach to enterprise bargaining. We now have a situation where only 22 per cent of Australians are covered by enterprise agreements. That indicates that the government has not progressed as far as it could have in improving the acceptance of this changed work system in the country. Twenty-two per cent of all workers is not a very high percentage. One could look at the higher proportion of public

theText: Facts, facts.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Slipper
theText: The whole idea of the class warfare of the 1890s should be dead and buriedMC 1422 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 sector workers who are covered by employment agreements, but one must observe the totality of the situation. When we have a position where only 22 per cent are covered it is fairly clear that the government really has not gone as far along the road as, indeed, it should have. The government also continues along the road of its scare campaign. We find that members opposite and the trade union movement go out into the newspapers and the various media outlets trying to suggest that we in the coalition are seeking to strip away basic working conditions and that we are seeking to return industrial relations to the law of the jungle. They are imputing bad motives to us and yet it is clear, if one looks at the major address made by the shadow minister for industrial relations, the member for Flinders( Mr Reith), only a short time ago, that what the government has been saying is simply incorrect. We ought to have honesty in politics, we ought to have accountability in politics and, indeed, we in the coalition will have honesty in policies. We will deliver our policies prior to the election and, what is more, when we are elected to office we will implement our policies, unlike the current government, which was prepared to say absolutely anything prior to the last election in order to crawl into office. Of course, once the current government was elected, the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) laughed in the faces of the Australian people and said, in effect, 'These are only promises to get us over the line. We're over the line and we're now tearing up these promises.' Remember the l-a-w tax cuts, and so on? It is a very sad indictment of the government's approach to politics to find that major players on the government's side continue to misrepresent our position. The Treasurer ( Mr Willis) says that we are seeking to hack away at these safety nets. The Minister for Industrial Relations says that we are seeking to take the machete to the award safety net and to cut it to pieces. The honourable member for Lilley( Mr Swan) says that Mr Reith is committed to abolishing the no-disadvantage test. The honourable member for Petrie( Mr Johns) says that we are seeking to demolish the very struts underneath our system of awards and that the nodisadvantage test will be kicked away. The reality is that the coalition will retain a nodisadvantage test; the shadow minister for industrial relations made that point very clearly. It probably will assist the chamber if I make it very clear what we intend to do as a coalition in the area of industrial relations after the next election. The thrust of coalition policy will be to ensure that Australian workers receive higher pay in more productive workplaces. The coalition will maintain the current award system overseen by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The coalition will support the jurisdiction of the AIRC to deliver safety net wage increases for the lowest paid workers. The coalition will establish minimum working conditions for agreements to ensure adequate protection, especially for the low paid workers. These conditions will include the relevant applicable classification award hourly rate. The coalition will make it easier for employers and employees to enter into direct negotiations about wages and conditions at individual workplaces. Obviously, for the workplaces with no union members, the coalition will not allow union bosses to intervene where they are not invited. Of course, that is a matter which will not please Ms George one iota. The coalition will ensure a fair go all round on the vexed unfair dismissals question. The coalition will restore section 45D and section 45E of the Trade Practices Act. We will support the right of workers to either belong to a union or not belong to a union and we will abolish union preference. If workers do want to belong to a particular union, the coalition will support their right to belong to a union of their choice and, as a result, the coalition will permit the dis-amalgamation of unions where this is the desire of the unionists themselves. We will retain Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1423 a fair and reasonable no-disadvantage test against a fair and reasonable set of minima. Of course, we find that government members opposite continue to go out into the media and continue to misrepresent our position. They stand condemned. It is clear from the report on enterprise bargaining that we are debating today that large sectors of the work force are not satisfied with what the government has achieved in the area of enterprise bargaining. It is clear that the minister is on the ropes with respect to enterprise bargaining. It is clear that the minister is no longer driving the agenda here: trade unions are, indeed, flexing their muscles and the minister is reacting to trade union pressure. It is obvious that large numbers of workers feel that they have not been consulted by the government on its reforms. They certainly have not been consulted on the way the government has implemented some of the enterprise bargaining. I think the minister ought to go back to basics. He ought to go back to the drawing board. He ought to pick up more than the coalition's words 'enterprise bargaining'. He ought to get to the substance of what we seek to achieve, which is, of course, to introduce a system of fairness, cooperation, productivity and flexibility. The minister has not been prepared to do that. The minister has not made anyone happy with his efforts. Women are upset by the report which has been handed down. Women's groups have claimed that women have not adequately benefited from the changes in the enterprise bargaining area. There has also been the suggestion that the enterprise bargaining that has occurred has favoured men. The simple fact of the matter is that only 22 per cent of Australian wage and salary workers-the earners-are currently covered by enterprise agreements. Sadly, the small business sector-the small work forces and the small workplaces-has hardly been touched by the enterprise bargaining arrangements. The large public sector and private sector businesses have largely picked up the enterprise bargaining changes that the minister has brought in. Unfortunately, so many of the award conditions which ought to be discussed between employers and employees have automatically been sucked up into those enterprise agreements. We support a reasonable set of minima. However, the government's whole approach to enterprise flexibility is exposed by the government's intention to support an appeal against the Tweed Valley Fruit Processors Pty Ltd enterprise flexibility agreement. This company was given $26,000 from the government's handouts which are designed to encourage EFA agreements. What happened was the EFA was approved by an overwhelming majority of employees and the AIRC, but its flexible sick leave provisions are now being challenged on appeal by the ACTU and the government is using taxpayers' money to support that appeal. Workers under this particular EFA have not given up their sick leave. In fact, they will be paid for eight days sick leave, the award provision, irrespective of whether they take it or not. Their right to take time off when they are sick is unaffected as is their protection against dismissal for absence because of illness. We have a situation where an EFA protects the workers. The EFA in effect says that, although people might on average take only half of their sick time, every worker will be paid for a full eight days sick pay whether or not the person is sick. If a person is sick, he or she is still able not to come to work. The government is appealing against this after it has contributed $26,000 of taxpayers' money to facilitate the negotiation of this very agreement. It is clear that the ACTU, yet again, has been able to crack the whip and the government has reacted to ACTU pressure. The workers and the employer are prepared to agree to this very reasonable arrangement and yet we find the ACTU is not happy. The ACTU is not happy MC 1424 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 that workers at Tweed Valley Fruit Processors Pty Ltd are going to get paid eight days sick pay, whether they are sick or not. It is bad enough for the ACTU to appeal, but to find that the minister and the government are prepared to support the appeal using more taxpayers' money, I think, is absolutely outrageous. That exposes, once and for all, the fact that the government's approach to enterprise flexibility is a complete and utter sham. The government gave $26,000 to encourage this agreement. Everyone talked about it; everyone agreed. We now find that, because the ACTU is not happy, the government is going to use taxpayers' money to, in effect, undermine, or seek to undermine, the agreement which $26,000 of taxpayers' money helped to promote. I think the government stands condemned. The government has failed in that only 22 per cent of employees are covered by enterprise flexibility agreements. The government has failed in that small business has not been covered adequately by these agreements. The government has failed in that real flexibility has not occurred. The government stands condemned because it has misrepresented the position of the coalition. It always undertakes scare campaigns, but the Australian people have seen through those scare campaigns. I believe that the Australian people are looking for honesty in politics. They are looking for accountability in government. The policy which will be announced by the coalition will be fair and reasonable. It will encourage enterprise flexibility agreements. The Australian people will support us at the next election. They will sweep those opposite from office as, indeed, they should be thrown out of government. (Time expired). the paper on the report Enterprise bargaining in Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will appreciate, probably better than most, that some quite provocative remarks have been made by speakers from the opposition. I want to respond in a wider context before I get down to the element of enterprise bargaining in Australia. I rejoice in being the member for Chifley. My electorate is named after Ben Chifley, a man who had a distinguished record not only in the trade union movement but also in the Labor Party, and as Treasurer and Prime Minister of this country. I am proud to belong to the Australian Labor Party which is a part of the wider labour movement; that is, the movement with an industrial wing comprising unions, and a political wing comprising the Australian Labor Party. I, too, have had a modest involvement in unions, for which I make no apology. I do not understand why opposition members seek to deride organisations that have as their aim and sole objective representing ordinary workers-the ordinary men and women of Australia, the ordinary young people of Australia. I find nothing inherently wrong in it. In fact, I think it is a real tragedy that only approximately 25 per cent of the work force in Australia is now represented by unions. Time after time in my electorate I have seen people being taken advantage of in the workplace because they have no union representation. One of the first principles that the opposition needs to understand is that people do not necessarily come to the workplace equally empowered. That is certainly true of a lot of employees. We have seen a lot of changes in the 13 years of Labor government. We need to remind ourselves what the industrial scene was like prior to the election of a Labor government. There was, for example, a wages blow-out. That is, workers were getting wage increases, but inflation
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Price (Chifley) (12.46 P.m.)
theText: I am pleased to speak on this motion to take note ofWednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 1425 was very high and so they were not getting the real benefit of those increases and it was like a dog chasing its own tail. There were a lot of industrial disputes, one might even say confrontations, sometimes actually provoked by the previous government. It goes without saying that this government has enjoyed a record period of industrial harmony. But, more than that-and I think this is central to this proposition of enterprise bargaining-the previous industrial scene was characterised by highly structured unions, by demarcation disputes, and by a management system where confrontation was promoted. I will demonstrate the change in the relationship between employees and employers in this period of Labor government. I was a member-as was the member opposite-of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training when it was doing an inquiry on skills. I was talking to one of the union delegates at a paper mill and he said, 'Before the changes here'-and he was talking about productivity agreements and multi skilling-'what we used to do is clock on, and, when we clocked on, we left our brains behind.' I thought that was a very insightful description of the paucity of the situation. I spoke about the issue of multi skilling. We have seen in the metals trade some 300-odd different awards collapsed into nine-the idea that a worker not only can do one job but is trained to do a number of jobs. These were, and are, revolutionary changes compared with what there was before. What does enterprise bargaining cement? It cements the idea that both employers and employees are stakeholders in organisations, that they need to cooperate constructively and that they can do that within the framework of enterprise bargaining, such that both are not disadvantaged and such that both are advantaged. It is very interesting in this report that workers covered by enterprise agreements, on average, are getting higher wage increases than those that are not. Here is another important point from a Labor perspective: we have never believed that the way forward is by reducing wages-in other words, that we can fuel further economic growth by slashing and hacking at ordinary workers' wages. I regret to say that there is so much in what I hear of the contributions of honourable members opposite and in their thinking that indicates that this still has a central place within the coalition. Enterprise bargaining is not about that. Enterprise bargaining is about two groups sitting down and discussing their conditions of employment, and changes to those conditions of employment, such that neither is disadvantaged and both are advantaged, and workers actually get increases. It is about harnessing the knowledge, enthusiasm and ideas of workers to make constructive input into the workplace. This was not the case. This was a rare exception in 1983 but now it is almost so commonplace that we take it for granted. The honourable member for Fisher( Mr Slipper) says, 'Oh, it's terrible.' He says that the unions bribed the government and we are introducing legislation to satisfy the unions. We have made no secret of the fact that we belong to a labour movement. We make no secret of the fact that we consult with unions. But we consult with a lot of other people. Let me give you an example, Mr Deputy Speaker. At one stage I was responsible for defence industry policy and we were doing a review. It is true that I consulted with the unions; I consulted with the ACTU. Basically, I went out to the factory floors and consulted with the employers and some of the employees. A statistical analysis would show that we consulted more with the employees than we did with the unions or the ACTU. MC 1426 MAIN COMMITfEE Wednesday, 20 September 1995 That is the Labor way-we like to listen: we do not like to reject ideas; we like to consult. And we have disagreements from time to time. You would never believe it, listening to the honourable member for Fisher. But of course we are interested in the welfare of ordinary people. That is what the Labor Party is all about. We are interested in how workers are faring. We want them to be the winners out of any system, not the losers. Maybe that is what distinguishes us. I should mention another centrality in our approach to labour relations. We have been able to sit down with the ACTU and develop accords. Unlike the history of John Howard when he was Treasurer, we have not had a wages explosion. We have done very constructive things for the so-called social wage. We have done things that I am inordinately proud of that the Liberal Party or the conservatives wish to destroy in government. Let me give you an example. We have negotiated the situation so that ordinary workers, as opposed to private enterprise executives or public servants, should have the benefit of superannuation, and it is compulsory. We are going to make sure they do not dip out. What do the opposition want to do? They want to do exactly what they did with the national welfare fund, which they destroyed. They are destroyers of workers' superannuation. A fully funded superannuation fund in the 1940s was destroyed by Menzies in the 1950s. Now we are saying in the 1990s that every worker ought to have a reasonable entitlement to his own superannuation. We think this is a measure long overdue but we do not think this measure lacks equity. We do not think it is unfair. But what do opposition members want to do about it? They say, 'Look, this is wrong. This is coercion. What we should be doing is the old Liberal trick of putting rorts into the tax system, getting rid of the compulsion and then if people want to save for their superannuation they can.' That used to be the system under which everyone had the same opportunity to save but women hardly had it at all and ordinary workers did not have it at all. We have changed that. I just hope that the ordinary people of Australia understand that, while our system of industrial relations has meant that they have had to make many changes, for which I thank them, and many sacrifices, for which I thank them, these things are under jeopardy at the next election. Do not assume for one moment that the Liberal Party will somehow abandon this fixation of wanting to see workers unrepresented. We had the member for Fisher saying, 'Well, of course, we're going to dis-amalgamate unions, we are going to allow them to dis-amalgamate,' when all the management theory says about organisations that you need to have a customer focus, that is, union members; you need to provide services, that is, services for union members; and the greater your revenue stream, that is, the larger the union, the greater potential you have to provide these services. This is somehow excommunicate anathema to opposition members. What they want to see is thousands of small unions. In fact, they would love to see an enterprise with 50 members have its own union. Well, I just do not understand it. I just do not understand why they want to attack ordinary people and their conditions of work this way. It doesn't make sense in management terms or organisational terms and it is a vicious attack on ordinary people. I was saying that workers have made a lot of sacrifices. I believe they have. They have seen a whole revolution occur in the workplace. As I have said, they have seen the demarcations go which used to provide them a measure of security, if you like, a measure of employmentnot something that I would justify. They have seen multi skilling come in. They have had to go back and get extra skills-be trained and re-trained. They have seen downsizing. They have Wednesday, 20 September 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1427 seen massive productivity increases. This is again a difference between a Labor government and a Liberal government: we believe that through work organisation, through new ways and better ways of doing it, through capital equipment, you can dramatically increase productivity, as we have. The other way we can increase productivity is to make labour cheaper. That is the conservative way. We reject that. We have seen lots of organisations downsize. BeforeI came to this place, I worked for Telecom. There have been massive changes and downsizing tnere and changes at a rate and pace that have almost been dysfunctional. That is not unique. It has been occurring right throughout Australia. People have adapted and coped and I congratulate them for that. I congratulate them for their positive approach. They have responded well to these changes. As this report suggests, enterprise bargaining is here to stay under a Labor government. Its reach will be increased dramatically. Ordinary men and women of Australia are not going to be disadvantaged in the process and we will not attack worker organisations. The enterprise bargaining report is a good report. As many people as possible should get hold of a copy of the report and they will find that the government has done well. (Time expired) Debate (on motion by Mr Lindsay) adjourned.
